Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: My phone buzzed as I pulled up to the next house on my delivery route. It was a message from Mom: “Haven’t heard from you today. Everything okay?” I glanced at the time—already past noon. I’d meant to text her this morning, but the rush of packages and addresses had swept me away. I typed a quick reply, but just as I was about to hit send, my work app pinged: “Urgent—confirm delivery with photo.” I looked at the package in my passenger seat, the address matching the house in front of me. No one was home, and the porch was exposed to the street. I needed to find a safe spot, take a photo, and upload it immediately. My fingers hovered between my phone’s messaging app and the delivery app. I could almost hear Mom’s worried voice, but my supervisor’s warning echoed too: “No shortcuts—secure every package.” My heart pounded as I stared at both screens, torn between reassuring my mom and meeting my job’s demands.
